title: An accurate and revised version of optical character recognition-based speech synthesis using LabVIEW
author: Prateek Mehta (Birla Institute of Technology, India), Anasuya Patil (Birla Institute of Technology, India), ...
relevance_why: The paper focuses on Optical Character Recognition (OCR) and Speech Synthesis systems, which may provide insights for developing similar systems in audio processing.
background: This work centers on creating a system that converts printed text into spoken words to aid visually impaired individuals, utilizing optical character recognition technology.
contribution: This paper introduces an OCR-based speech synthesis system implemented in LabVIEW to improve accessibility for visually impaired users, achieving a high level of text recognition accuracy.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous OCR systems faced challenges regarding accuracy, font compatibility, and speed of text-to-speech conversion.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work enhances efficiency by integrating improved character recognition and customizable speech synthesis in a user-friendly environment.

key_innovation: Utilizes LabVIEW software to streamline the conversion of scanned documents into speech, enabling real-time audio outputs.
real_world_impact: The proposed system can significantly enhance educational access for visually impaired individuals and has the potential for wider applications in assistive technology.

new_terms.optical character recognition: **Optical Character Recognition (OCR)** is a technology that converts different types of documents, such as scanned paper documents or PDFs, into editable and searchable data.
new_terms.LabVIEW: **Laboratory Virtual Instrument Engineering Workbench (LabVIEW)** is a system-design platform and development environment from National Instruments that allows for visual programming.
